Fields.DialogueText: Captain! I need your help.
Hold on. I just need to brace myself appropriately.
... Just what have the other Belles asked you to do?
Nothing we need to dwell on.
Such a hard life you lead among ravishing ship spirits. This will be easy, though!
Now I'm really concerned.
I need your help thinking up a new plan.

Fields.MenuText: A plan for what, exactly?
A new battle plan? We'll cover it at the weekly tactical meeting.
If this ends with us hunting down a Morgana battleship again...

Fields.DialogueText: That's just the thing. I'm... not entirely sure.
Wrong kind of plan, Captain, but good thinking.
It won't! Probably!
With Treason handed a black eye and my reputation repaired, I find my hands idle.
Something that plays to my strengths, my full suite of skills... not just fighting.
I see why you've been having a tough time with this. It seems like just yesterday I couldn't get you to a diplomatic function without the promise of a decapitation.
Well, it would have been gauche of me to show up without a gift.
*ALARM*
And here come exhibits A through... however many.
@BATTLE
Idle hands being the devil's playground, I need some sort of project to work on.
Captain! Who was that who just left your office? I didn't recognize him.
That would be Commander Sir Edward Redviper, Royal Navy and now INPF personnel officer for this region.
He was talking to me about some of the morale issues we're facing.
Now there's a constant battle. Sailors far from home can always be happier.
I agree. Though I'm not sure about some of his suggestions. Hiring a trio of wandering Italian chefs he knows to supplement our galley crew, for example.
If they were any good, would they really be wandering?
Apparently they used to cook for General Melchett and Field Marshal Sir Douglas Haig during the Great War.
They must be ancient by now! Still, what's the use of improving things for just one ship?

Fields.MenuText: I agree. If anything, have them teach our cooks how to innovate with galley fare.
Just as long as they don't start a god-awful propaganda rag.
Showing regular people what's out here could go along way. The other world war, you know.

Fields.DialogueText: An astute suggestion, if they're really that skilled.
You never know when you might run low on toilet paper.
One we're all fighting. Save perhaps for the most landlocked of nations, and even they do what they can.
I'll have to think about it.
Well, let me know if you have any flashes of inspiration. I'm sure Redviper and his superiors would be very interested.
Inspiration's my business, Captain! Not to mention the occasional scrap...
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Noisy out on deck today. Band practice?
Band practice indeed. Recruit's really got them working hard today.
Nasty out there, isn't it?
I'll whip things back into tune, Captain.
Pardon?
Oh, you'll see, Captain. You'll see.
@BATTLE
Captain, Lieutenant! Did you appreciate the concert?
Excellent as always. I wouldn't expect a ship this size to have a full band.
What the skipper said. If you'll excuse me...
I always feel better after hearing the band play their hearts out.
Music tends to do that to people.
Maybe that's something we can do for fleet morale! A new song, perhaps?

Fields.MenuText: For the whole INPF? That's a tall order.
I know the crew appreciates it, but that's hard to replicate on a fleetwide scale.
No, I think it's missing something. We need a broader brush to paint with...

Fields.DialogueText: Finding universal appeal? That just means it's a challenge!
True. Very few ships have much more than a bosun's whistle or the occasional harmonica.
Hmm... perhaps some visual art, then?
This problem's been keeping me up at night, to tell you the truth.
... Do you even need to sleep?
Well... no. Actually. But I like to! Sometimes.
Fair enough. I'd like to sleep more.
I feel like I'm not making much progress on it. And I invented it.
Don't force it. If you made it, you can unmake it.
I used to say that about my recruits.
Did you?
No. But if they ever got unruly, I thought about it real hard.
So that's how it is, Captain. I'm getting a lot of flak from back home.
Right, the actual belligerent nations. Who even knows what kind of news those folks are getting?
I'm sure a lot of the other fellas are getting the same. Especially the Brits, the Germans...
I couldn't begin to guess, Captain. I imagine not much. The INPF doesn't seem to censor too much, but...
But it's just a bit too much to believe. I know. All right. I'll see what I can do.
Make sure to keep an eye out for your shipmates, especially from the belligerent powers. They need our support. Dismissed.
Aye-aye, Captain.
What was that about, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: The same problem we've been tackling recently.
What we expected. The home fronts putting pressure on their sailors.
For every person that believes in you Belles, it seems there's two or more doubters.

Fields.DialogueText: Mhmm. That sailor looked pretty distraught, too.
Morale is a complex problem, isn't it? It's not just the sailors, or them and their families, but whole nations.
It is hard to believe. It's not unfair for people to doubt... or jut not want to believe.
People just might not have enough context for dealing with the reality of the Morganas.
Or they're focusing on the land war. It's more immediate to them. That makes it more real.
Which makes the Morganas just another distraction.
Well, we'll just have to make it real! Then they'd treat it seriously.
Morganas! Morganas to port!
Careful what you wish for. Battle stations!
@BATTLE
Hmm... No, that's not it.
Recruit?
Ah! Captain! I was just working on some notes.
About the morale problems? Any interesting brain waves?
It's complicated.
Well, we knew that.
I think we can only really tackle this from one end: the sailors, or the general populace.
We are only one officer and one nigh-immortal warship spirit, after all.
Har har. You should have been a comedian.
Seriously, though. Which end of the problem do you think we should focus on?

Fields.MenuText: The civilian population. If we treat the source, we should get results.
The crews. Give them the tools and knowledge they need to help back home.
It's a big enough problem that I can't be sure. There's really no way to tackle the whole thing?

Fields.DialogueText: We have to start from somewhere, though the civilians might be the bigger challenge.
We have easy access to the crews and the support infrastructure to reach them, after all.
Helping with one should help the other, but I'm honestly not sure.
This was a lot easier during the Great War.
Relatively clean lines in that conflict. I even...
Hey, that's an idea!
*ALARM*
Save it! Meet you on the bridge!
Oh, you are not going to want to miss it!
@BATTLE
Gah! Fine. Not like this clutter's going anywhere.
@BATTLE
Damn, damn, damn! Where did I put it?
Recruit, it can wait! We're about to start shooting!
Hah! I knew it was here somewhere. Hey! You there! Go fetch a couple sheets and a bosun's mate.
Carry on. Recruit, what's all this mess?
Aye-aye, ma'am! Oh, excuse me, Captain.
I found it! My projector! I just need to improvise a screen.
Like a movie projector?
Precisely. It's only set up for silent films, but I bet I can wrangle an upgrade from the INPF.

Fields.MenuText: Going to show some old classics?
You know when I commented on propaganda films, that wasn't a suggestion.
Hmm. I think I see where you're going with this.

Fields.DialogueText: That's right. I have a cunning plan!
Propaganda's all what you make of it, Captain.
As expected of my captain.
As far as lifestyle changes go, I figure movie night will be an easy sell.
We can mix in some war movies, the kind to lift the spirit... some lighter fare for higher moods...
There's other types I wanted to use, but I'm pretty sure they don't exist.
Like what?
INPF training films, for one. Ship recognition, operation, some of the universal hand signals we've developed...
Sounds like something our friend Commander Redviper might be interested in.
It does indeed! I still need to think about it, but once I have a plan, would you submit the proposal?
Of course. Keep me posted. I'm curious to see what you come up with.
Well, I have to say that movie night was a rousing success!
If you do say so yourself.
And I do! Little luxuries and time away from grumpy petty officers and hard work can be worth more than rum.
Don't let the Chief hear you say that. She'll lay into you for heresy.
The Chief's an old salt before her time. Besides, even she enjoyed the movies.
Did you know I was a movie star once upon a time, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: You know, you do look familiar...
Really?
Wait, recently? Or before, when you were asleep?

Fields.DialogueText: Captain, you don't have to look at me so intensely.
You don't have to sound so surprised.
When I was asleep, of course. I'd hope you'd notice a film crew aboard.
So what movie were you--
*ALARM*
I guess that'll have to wait. Morganas!
That's our cue to hit the bridge!
@BATTLE
Look at us go! I could really use that film crew right about now...
@BATTLE
Captain! There you are. About our last conversation...
About you being a movie star?
Surely you've seen the movie I did with Charles Richman? Over There! It's a classic.

Fields.MenuText: Can't say I've ever heard of it.
Recruit, I'm pretty sure I was in short pants when that was released.
Isn't that a song?

Fields.DialogueText: Well, you wouldn't hear it. It was a silent picture!
That's no excuse for not taking in culture, Captain!
The song inspired the title of the movie, of course!
It was a great movie - all about the AEF going overseas to fight the Great War.
So how did you feature?
Who better to have in your film than a bona fide New York-class battleship?
One conveniently located on land for filming, too.
Correct! It'd be fun to remake it with all this new technology, though. I could even sing the song!
Over there, over there. Send the word, send the word over there. That the Yanks are coming!
With my sisters leading the charge, of course.
New York was the only American warship to sink an enemy ship during the Great War, you know.
... Didn't she get rammed accidentally by a U-boat?
Details, details. A kill's a kill.
You're quite proud of your sisters, aren't you?
Very. They're both amazing. Powerful. Graceful. It's a lot to live up to.
I'm sure they're proud of you, too. Even during the Great War, you were pretty impressive.
I graduated 25,000 sailors at least! They don't call me Recruit for nothing!
Captain! I've decided what my next plan is.
Ah, hello, Recruit. No, I'm not busy. Please, come in and sit down.
Har har. Seriously, though.
Well, don't keep me in suspense.
I'm going to make a movie!

Fields.MenuText: How the hell are we going to pay for that?
Doesn't that mean going into dry dock or tying up at the pier for a while?
Hmm. What kind of movie, though?

Fields.DialogueText: We won't, of course. The INPF will.
No, the entire point will be to avoid any impact on our operational status.
I'm glad you asked, Captain!
I'm going to make a series of INPF training films.
I want to help our sailors and make sure we have a strong base of knowledge.
There's a lot of rumor and folklore circulating about the Morganas, after all. If any of that makes it home, it can have knock-on effects.
Or a sailor might not even know how to explain it, which might make them seem less trustworthy or something.
Exactly. The scale of the problem is significant, and an educated force can educate their kin.
It's a solid theory, Recruit. I hope it works.
I've already done up a letter to Commander Redviper. I'll send it along with your permission.
Send the message. There's no harm in seeing where this goes.
That's the spirit, Captain. This will work, I promise you!
*ALARM*
Hold that thought. I'll send the message after we send this Morgana to the bottom!
@BATTLE
Keep the seas clear! I'm expecting a very important message!
Priorities, Recruit.
@BATTLE
Is that from Commander Redviper?
The very same. Seems we've been given a go-ahead order.
Along with a more or less blank check to bring on supplies and the like.
Even hire specialists, if you feel they're needed.
They're trusting us completely on this? That's a lot of faith in us.

Fields.MenuText: You don't think we're up to the task?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, no, I know we are. Just flattered, is all.

Fields.MenuText: Why wouldn't they? This is us we're talking about, after all.

Fields.DialogueText: Excellent point. Honestly, they should just turn the whole enterprise over.

Fields.MenuText: We'll have to make sure we pay that trust back in full.

Fields.DialogueText: We will, Captain. We have to. This is for the whole INPF, after all!
I'll start planning at once.
I want to make this project run seamlessly, and that means measuring a bare minimum of twice before we cut.
I'll leave it to you, then. If you need help, you know where to find me.
You'll be the first to know once I have a rough draft, Captain. I won't let you, the sailors, or the folks back home down!
Oh, Captain, good timing! Hold this string.
... All right, what's the string for?
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Recruit, I hate to ask, but what the hell is all this?
I'm diagramming subjects that I think we need to cover.
There's... a lot already.
Which is why I'm diagramming it. I'll take that, thank you.
... There. It's a matter of figuring out what topics best fit where, you see.
Hold that thought!
All right, back to business. What do you think of my planning so far?

Fields.MenuText: Looks... complicated.
Are you sure you need all of this stuff?
Looks like you've got an infestation of yarn spiders.

Fields.DialogueText: Very! But I think it'll be fine.
Pretty sure. I've been reviewing everything in exquisite detail.
Captain, I'd appreciate if you took this seriously.
Well, keep me updated.
Will do. I... oh. Hold this string, now would you?
As if the paperwork wasn't enough.
After we get through this, a little bureaucracy won't seem so bad.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Keep telling yourself that...
All right, Captain, here are those documents I mentioned. All for you to sign.
... Ye gods and little fishes. Recruit, what is all this stuff?
Requisition orders for specialized equipment, personnel... I did warn you, Captain.
I suppose the INPF did give you carte blanche on this. All right, put it all on my desk.
... And maybe bring me a support for my wrist.

Fields.MenuText: So have you refined your plan for me to see?
Hmm. Some of these documents are kind of wild themselves.
Recruit, do we really not have some of this stuff? Surely we have at least a handful of INPF uniforms.

Fields.DialogueText: You saw it the other day, Captain! You even helped with some of the string.
All according to plan, Captain, I assure you.
None in good condition. Uniform wear was something we always stressed in my recruiting days.
Thank you again, Captain. Want me to fetch you some tea or something while you're working?
Coffee from the Chief's mess. It seems I'm going to be here for a while.
Right away, Captain! I'll be right back.
Finally an enemy I can shoot...
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Recruit? Are you in here? Among this... absolute ocean of paperwork? Good lord.
Oh, Captain! What can I do for you?
Tell me, how much paperwork have you generated for this project? What is all this stuff?
Well, there's the requisition forms you signed the other day, a variety of manuals...
... Newspapers, declassified intelligence reports, the first few pages of about a dozen scripts...

Fields.MenuText: This would be a fire hazard anywhere, never mind aboard a warship who frequently sees action.
I feel like this project is getting out of hand somewhat.
Recruit... have you actually finished any scripts? Or started filming?

Fields.DialogueText: Hmm. You may actually have a point there.
No, no, just a lot of details I need to cover properly, that's all.
Oh, it's far too early for that, Captain! I have more research to do.
I mean, gun loading procedures across the INPF could be the subject of an entire thesis.
Did you know that we have over two hundred variants of naval rifle in active service?
It certainly feels like we do when I fill out requisition forms.
The INPF's logistics corps really deserve more credit.
It's like the old saying goes. Amateurs talk tactics, the experienced talk strategy, experts talk logistics.
I wonder if we could educate sailors up to at least the experienced level with this sort of program.
That seems a bit out of the scope of basic training, doesn't it?
The better educated they are, the more effective they'll be, Captain!
We're all in this together, after all. Trust me.
ARGH!
Never mind. I seem to have located her.
Finally a break from signing these things. Recruit sure doesn't do anything halfway...
@BATTLE
Lieutenant, have you seen Recruit?
No, Captain, she hasn't been on the bri--
Recruit? Are you okay?
Yes! No. Maybe?
I'll go with no for now. What's with all these papers all over the passageway?
I tripped on a kneeknocker and dropped everything.
Captain, did you know that over a dozen major languages are commonly spoken aboard INPF ships?

Fields.MenuText: I'm shocked that it's that few.
Everyone seems to speak English around here.
Huh. You know, everyone seems to act like the other Belles speak their mother tongue.

Fields.DialogueText: I did say "major." As in a statistically significant sample of sailors.
Well, I am an American ship. It makes sense that our INPF augmentees would learn the predominant tongue.
They do! Well, the captains do. Belles can always understand their chosen captains. It wouldn't be very helpful if we couldn't.
So what's that have to do with the sheer volume of documents in this passageway?
... Wait, are these more requisition forms?
These are all for linguists and language material.
Right! We have to get the material translated into as many languages as possible.
Thanks for helping me pick up, Captain.
... This is getting out of hand.
Oh! Hello, Captain! Please come in! Just, ah... watch the string.
What a tangled web you weave, Recruit.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
You've added some colors since I was last in here.
Can I ask what the heck it all means?
Well, first, I was connecting related subjects and subjects that would flow well in a course of instruction, either together or sequentially.
Then I started to prioritize... everything.
Recruit, I'm starting to get--
There's so much vital information to communicate. It's all vital, in its own way.

Fields.MenuText: Right... "prioritize."
Most of this seems like technical training.
Even I don't know half of this stuff.

Fields.DialogueText: Technical information is critical to one's job as a sailor or officer, after all.
Just goes to show how outdated our training process is.
What was that, Captain?
Nothing! Get to the bridge!
I'm almost glad some of those bitches showed up. I could use a little exercise.
*ALARM*
Finally. I can pretend she hasn't colonized my quarters...
@BATTLE
Is that mountain of paperwork... moving?
Maybe this is finally the day I completely lose my mind.
Maybe I've been crazy this whole time. This has all been a hallucination as I die clinging to a plank of driftwood or something.
All right, that goes with the rest...
Oh, it's just Recruit. Well, that's one crisis resolved.
Captain! Good timing! Lend me a hand, would you?
Recruit... I'm afraid to ask, but is this the same mountain of paperwork from last time?
Oh, no, this is a new stack!

Fields.MenuText: I'm not sure I want to know the details.
Don't you think this is getting off course, Recruit?
Recruit, you're going to deforest a continent at this rate.

Fields.DialogueText: I doubt we have time to go over them all, honestly.
Hmm? No, not at all, Captain. I have everything under control. Mostly.
I really have been trying to minimize things, Captain.
This is a set of requests for a survey of film equipment across the fleet.
Then a prospective set of orders for film reels in various sizes.
Once I have all that data, I'll generate a proposal to send to HQ on which types of film to purchase in which languages.
We might have to record several times instead of just dubbing voiceovers.
That sounds... complicated.
Recruit, are you sure there isn't an easier way to do this?
Sometimes you just have to roll up your sleeves and get to work, Captain.
I have to do something. This clearly isn't going to get better on its own.
Hoist away!
Almost done taking on supplies, Captain.
Excellent. I want to get under way quickly. Never know when a sub's lurking around...
Wait, what's that last one?
Whatever it is, Captain, it's heavy!
Manifest says it's books and technical manuals.
Who requisitioned that?
Take one guess, Captain.
Send that crate back to the supply ship. I need to go talk to Recruit.
Captain, did you just come from the bridge? I was hoping to receive my shipment personally.
That's why I'm looking for you. Recruit, this has gone too far.
You just had multiple tons of technical documents shipped in.
I was just making sure my data was accurate, Captain! What's the problem with that?

Fields.MenuText: Because you're generating an unholy amount of dense material that probably won't be fit for purpose.
Why do you think you need all that data to start with?
Remind me why you originally wanted to do this?

Fields.DialogueText: What? How can that possibly be? The information needs to be accurate, after all.
How else can I instruct clearly without all of it?
I... why I originally wanted to do this?
I think I need to rethink this, Captain. I--
*ALARM*
Save it for later. We have to do our real jobs first.
With pleasure, Captain!
@BATTLE
Captain, do you have a moment?
Do you need me to hold more string?
No, I've cleaned all that up.
Then I have all the time in the world for you, Recruit.
I think I figured out the problem with my plan.
The critical problem, I mean.
The original point of all this was to help the sailors communicate things back home.

Fields.MenuText: Technical training has always best been carried out by senior sailors anyway.
Ships, the sea, guns, torpedoes... all that varies across the fleet. The threat doesn't.
We need our sailors to truly comprehend the threat they face, whatever their reasons for joining us.

Fields.DialogueText: True. That is the tradition dating all the way back to the age of sail.
Educating every sailor on everything specific to their job really is an impossible task, even for a Belle.
We do take all kinds from all backgrounds.
I'm going back to the drawing board.
Sounds like a great idea to me.
Care to help me this time, Captain? I feel like trying to do it all alone didn't help, either.
Gladly, Recruit. Let's get this done.
*ALARM*
Damn them to Davy Jones! Just when I was all fired up to work!
@BATTLE
It's almost a relief to get out here again...
@BATTLE
So we need a new plan.
No, I don't actually think we do.
The plan's fine. The objective is not.
You let things grow out of control, so a limited objective is fine.
Well, where do you think we should draw the line, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: I wonder if we could get some cartoons done about the Morganas.
Our original plan was to focus on the Morganas. I see no reason to change.
I can't even remember why we started doing this, honestly.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not sure we can afford the going rate for magic, but the studio might volunteer!
That's true. They're mysterious, but they can be understood in a base way.
Because sailors were getting angry letters from back home asking why they weren't in their national navies.
I think I have it.
We just need to reduce everything down to a few simple films, or maybe even something like a field manual.
Just the bare amount of information required to fully understand our situation.
And to fully understand the scope of the threat we face specifically.
There's still a lot of moving parts, though.
Just don't overthink it, and I think you'll be fine.
Maybe ask the sailors and see what they want to know.
That's a good idea! I'll ask some of the other Belles to ask around too next time we're in port.
Captain! A moment, if you please?
I please. What is it, Recruit?
I'd like to review my plan for the actual distribution of materials while we wait for results.
I've simplified things down to cover the five largest languages in the INPF: English, French, German, Japanese, and Italian.
Coincidentally making up the bulk of the world's naval power.
Coincidentally. For others, the only thing to do is to get fluent speakers to translate for their shipmates.
Which makes it a local issue for the Belle in question, and something they will likely already havea solution for.
Correct. I was also thinking about whether we should send films to the other ships at all.

Fields.MenuText: So where would they be sent?
That's problematic. The INPF has a pretty aggressive operations tempo.
So you're thinking to catch sailors when they're in port?

Fields.DialogueText: To various INPF naval bases, or out to a fleet on request and then passed between ships.
I've got that factored in, Captain.
Yes, preferably on formally enlisting. I was thinking we'd make it more of an event, feed them, that sort of thing.
Sending the reels to major activity centers is a pretty good idea.
It simplifies a lot of things. The INPF can send out a projector set to each base for relatively little.
If the base doesn't have one already.
Precisely.
Recruit, I think you've got this thing properly figured out at last.
I agree, Captain. Unfortunately, we'll have to postpone this discussion.
Guests?
Guests. I'm warming up a 14" hors d'oeuvre for them right now!
@BATTLE
The results are in, Captain!
Good. Bring them here and let's hear some of them.
All right, let's make this quick!
@BATTLE
I've reviewed a few. There's a lot of questions about Belles, actually.
I feel like some of them would be better explained by just interacting with your own ships's Belle, honestly.
There's only one of you per ship, and sometimes thousands of sailors and officers.
Point. Do we need to eat? No, but most Belles like to.
I feel like most of those questions have already been asked by the Captain's Association, too.

Fields.MenuText: Being privy to those transmissions generally means being a captain, though.
We can't all be early war veteran captains, Recruit.
Sounds like we can dig up the transcripts of those meetings to answer those questions, then.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, that's a good point. I hadn't thought of that.
True. I suppose the material would potentially be less engaging for newer captains.
That's a good point. No sense doubling up the work for more complex subjects.
Here's one in French and I... oh. Oh, my.
What is it?
A cross between a bawdy question and a love letter, I think.
Not from one of our sailors, I'll assume.
No, this is from a batch of questions I got from a French Belle I met in port.
I wonder if she actually read the letter.
Considering that it looks like it was slashed by a bayonet, I'd say yes.
And was none too pleased about it, clearly.
It was a very rude question, Captain. The French might have a reputation for being passionate, but there are limits.
Seems that kind of education will handle itself, thankfully. At bayonet point, possibly.
I'm sure it does wonders for retention of manners. At the very least, I'm sure the sailor in question got her point.
Hmm... that's good. Move that here...
Hard at work, I see. How goes it, professor?
Hardly a professor. Though I will take "Doctor," being that I am one.
It's going well. Bad Bill snuck in and ate a few pages, but nothing irrecoverable.
Excellent. So the plan is three reels now?
Correct. I'm looking at the scripts for basic explanations of what a Belle is and what the Morganas are.

Fields.MenuText: What are those hags besides nightmares?
Feels like you could clean that up with a dictionary definition.

Fields.DialogueText: ... To the best of our knowledge, anyway.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe you can do a children's book too.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, that's the problem. There's lots of superstition around a threat that's all too grounded and real.
That wouldn't be terribly satisfying, though. Not for me or for the sailors.
That would be fun. I'd need to find an artist to help, though.
There's just a lot of small details to answer for people.
It's the details that make the difference, though. It makes us more real.
More human?
In a sense, though some of us are more human than others.
I suppose for long-time sailors, Belles are self-explanatory on some level. It's what makes this sort of thing hard to explain.
Right. How do you explain that water is wet to someone who's never seen it?
One Marine I talked to had a nice way of putting it.
"Ma'am, when you Belles revealed yourselves, for us it just meant our faith was validated. Any man worth his salt always knew you were there."
Poetic.
Very. We don't know much about our own existence, but I can't help but feel that faith like that is why we're here.
Very possibly.
Since the very first sailors, they have lived in us, relied on us, cursed us... and through it all, loved us.
Mother, sister, lover... even without a Belle in person, they've loved their ships, these men of the sea.
And in dark times, be it by nature or by man's wrath, we've sheltered them... in life and in death, together in the sea's embrace.
There's magic in emotions like that. In love like that. In faith like that.
No matter what really brought us forth. There's a magic in us, born of and forged by man.
Now we walk alongside you for a time... hopefully to return to rest. Where we will wait, faithfully, until we're needed again.
Excellent. I knew the Captain's Association had logs of the first hours of the Morgana war.
Why that specifically, though?
I have those transcripts you asked for. They finally came through via courier.
This is the most critical of the three reels of film, Captain. It explains the threat.
I can think of few things more important than making sure everyone knows what happened at the start.
The Morganas attacked almost every major port in the world nigh-simultaneously.
Schleswig-Holstein fired her first salvo at the Westerplatte and the mists rolled in.
After that the fight was on everywhere. I remember.
It really illustrates the scale of the threat. Any force that can mount a strike like that on that scale...

Fields.MenuText: Honestly, Recruit, this might be your hardest sell, because I don't want to believe it.
I just wish the Morganas had to follow the same rules we do in terms of logistics.
Make sure to keep it positive. This is a fight we can win.

Fields.DialogueText: I know, Captain. I think that's where most of the resistance comes from.
Who knows what goes on in their maelstroms? They do seem to raid for some supplies, at least.
It's not a fight we can win, Captain. It's a fight we must win.
Honestly, the Morganas are fighting every human navy more or less simultaneously to a draw. It's hard to conceive of a scale more massive than that.
They really are an impressive foe in that sense. But that's all the more reason to defeat them.
Well said.
*ALARM*
Feel up to some defeating?
Let's.
@BATTLE
Captain, I have good news!
Oh? Something with your project?
I sent the scripts to HQ for review, and they're putting them into production immediately!
I was looking forward to filming them myself, but they have nicer equipment ashore.
Plus they'll be able to put them into production much more quickly.
Nice work, Recruit. I believe class is formally in session.
Thanks for all your help on this, Captain. And for pointing out when I was... being a touch extreme.

Fields.MenuText: We're a team, Recruit. Looking out for each other is what we do.
No need to thank me. You help me all the time.
You really were going a tad wild there for a bit.

Fields.DialogueText: A fair point, but you still deserve thanks.
And you always make it a point to thank me, Captain.
Ugh, I know. What in the world was I thinking?
I'm looking forward to a chance to relax for a bit.
Going back to holding soirees for the diplomatic corps?
Or focusing entirely on fighting the war. Though I wouldn't mind a gala or two.
*ALARM*
Well, if combat helps relax you, it seems you're going to be very relaxed until the war ends.
If anyone needs a lesson, it's the Morganas.
You don't come at the INPF and USS Recruit lightly!
@BATTLE
So, anything of further note?
The Chief was saying we had an uptick in letters going home.
See, Captain? The future's looking brighter already.
Another day, another fleet.
You know our crew, Captain. We came prepared!
@BATTLE
Not sure why. Morale is generally good, so it's not bellyaching.
We did just screen the text footage for Recruit's training films.
It'd be great if it had that kind of impact.
Might be a lot of them had questions from kinfolk they didn't quite know how to answer. I'd say your classes likely helped with that greatly, ma'am.
Excuse me, Skipper. I'm going to go assume my watch.
Kind of makes me wish I could read some of the letters.

Fields.MenuText: No one likes a snoop, Recruit.

Fields.DialogueText: I know, I know! I'm just curious.
I already sent off the feedback to the INPF.

Fields.MenuText: You could just ask the censors.
I think we can glean all the knowledge we need from the general state of morale.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, that's a good point... but I really shouldn't.
That's true. And as the lieutenant said, it does seem to be good.
Good. That means they can make the changes and get the reels in production.
I'm excited, Captain. Hopeful. This could have a big impact on the fleet.
Of course it will. This is you we're talking about.
Those 25,000 sailors during the Great War were a pretty huge impact.
A fair number of those men are still in service, so you could say that that impact continues.
See? You make waves, and this is another fine feather in your cap.
I think this rates an extra ration of ice cream!
Just name the flavor.
